stages.text: It is 10:30 and you are in the Forum on your way to a lecture when the person that you are walking with starts complaining that they feel very weak and unwell.

questions.question: What would you want to do initially?
questions.answer: Sit her down somewhere before asking a few questions about how she is feeling.

stages.text: You sit her down and because she is already talking to you, you skip the primary survey and perform the secondary survey (/obs).
obs: S: She says that she's feeling very weak and a little faint. She is getting heart palpitations and her pulse feels strong and is bounding.

M: She uses preventer inhalers daily and reliever inhalers as and when she needs them. She is also a Type I diabetic and uses insulin to manage this. She has a continuous glucose monitoring device and uses insulin injections and insulin pens.
P: She has fairly well controlled asthma, and type I diabetes.
L: She was running late this morning and only managed to have a glass of apple juice for breakfast. She brought a cereal bar with her and hasn't had a chance to eat it just yet.
E: She has been feeling like this for around 10 minutes.

questions.question: What do you want to do?
questions.answer: It would be useful to have a blood glucose measurement. Given that she has a chronic health condition, it is very likely that she will be completely fine sorting this out herself, most people with Type I diabetes are very good at managing their condition and have the different supplies necessary to keep them healthy. It might just be that you are there to provide support.

questions.question: She checks her blood glucose and notes that it is 3.5 mmol/L. What is the normal range for blood sugar?
questions.answer: 4-7 mmol/L, so this is a little bit low.

questions.question: She asks you to get her something sugary to help treat her low blood sugar. What could you get?
questions.answer: 150-200 ml fruit juice or sugary drink, glucose tablet, small handful of sweets etc. Note that sugar-free drinks e.g. Coke Zero will be of no use.

questions.question: She eats/drinks what you give her and also eats her cereal bar, why does she eat the cereal bar?
questions.answer: Cereal bars have complex carbohydrates in them, these are slower acting and prevent a further dip in blood sugar after the initial intake of the simple carbohydrates.

questions.question: When should she do a repeat measurement of her blood glucose level?
